questions.question_text: Which of the following routing conventions is known as a link-state protocol?

discussion.content: Open Shortest Path First (OSPF) is a link-state routing protocol that was developed for IP networks and is based on the Shortest Path First (SPF) algorithm.

questions.question_text: A technician is making the population of routers more secure. Which of the following are the BEST options for making authentication more secure? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: Wow, for once the answer isn't "upgrade the firmware".

comments.content: Because Telnet could be used right now (aka NOT unused), which is why they want to improve authentication. So therefore it wouldn't be disabled, even though it's insecure.

discussion.content: Why not disable unused services then? It includes Telnet since the technicians want to make the routers more secure, and they surely know that telnet is insecure. Plus you would be disabling other unused services that can be exploited ...I would go B and E
It's talking about making AUTHENTICATION more secure, which means disabling Telnet and enabling Authentication, Authorization, and Accounting the viable answers. That's how it makes sense to me.
Best options for making "authentication" for secure, hmm the given answers seem correct.
There are better options than telnet. Haha You made me crazy.
Its says the best option disabling v is more secure that upgrading the firmware
Where does PoE come into play in the question? Wouldn't you want a layer 3 switch that has QoS features?

comments.content: This was a sneaky, tricky question. IMHO.
First you need a PoE switch to connect IP phones and secondly managed switches do support QoS configuration

discussion.content: Only rationale I have is ause technically... the question only asks what shoulder the technician install. Or in other words what else is needed here? It doesn't specifically ask what should be installed to resolve the QoS issue. It's a pretty stupid question
Layer 3 switch = managed switch + router. So, there are 2 correct answers
I think you should focus on "Managed" keyword here not PoE
I' m confused, of course PoE is needed for the VoIP, but the question seemed to be concerned about the QoS requirement.

questions.question_text: A technician is installing six PCs and six VoIP telephones on a small office LAN. The VoIP telephones require QoS to be configured for proper operation. The customer router does not have QoS capability. Which of the following network devices should the technician purchase and install at this office?

choices.A: The address provided by the ISP has a mask that is too small to be used and needs a larger mask.
choices.C: The address provided by the ISP is the wrong one; they should be using 172.17.10.252/30.
choices.D: The address provided by the ISP is part of the reserved loopback address space and cannot be used.
choices.B: The address provided by the ISP is a private IP address space and is not routable on the Internet.

discussion.content:
The organizations that distribute IP addresses to the world reserves a range of IP addresses for private networks.

 192.168.0.0 - 192.168.255.255 (65,536 IP addresses)
 172.16.0.0 - 172.31.255.255 (1,048,576 IP addresses)
 10.0.0.0 - 10.255.255.255 (16,777,216 IP addresses)
B is correct. Private IP are NOT routable and it will stay on the LAN. Remember that a server must have a public IP address to route from source to destination.

comments.content: IMO, those private addresses should be blocked by firewall... maybe that is why?

discussion.content: Factually incorrect. Private IP's are routeable. You just would not be able to or atleast would have a tonne of issues.

questions.question_text: A network administrator has signed up for service with a new ISP. The administrator was given the IP address of 172.17.10.254/30 to use on the external interface of the Internet-facing router. However, the network administrator cannot reach the Internet using that address. Which of the following is the MOST likely explanation?

discussion.content:
Network baselining is the act of measuring and rating the performance of a network in real-time situations. Providing a network baseline requires testing and reporting of the physical connectivity, normal network utilization, protocol usage, peak network utilization, and average throughput of the network usage.

Such in-depth network analysis is required to identify problems with speed and accessibility, and to find vulnerabilities and other problems within the network.

Once a network baseline has been established, this information is then used by companies and organizations to determine both present and future network upgrade needs as well as assist in making changes to ensure their current network is optimized for peak performance.

https://www.webopedia.com/definitions/network-baselining/
